Random Coordinate Descent Methods

This is a reading note on the paper “Random Coordinate Descent Methods for Minimizing Decomposable Submodular Functions” by A. ENE, Huy L. NGUYEN

arxiv

Knowledge prerequisite on submodular function (in Chinese):

子模函数以及Lovasz拓展

Preliminaries

Let V={1,2,…,n}V = \{1,2,\ldots, n\}V={1,2,…,n}.

Regarding w∈Rnw\in \mathbb{R}^nw∈Rn as a modular function w(A)=∑i∈Awiw(A) = \sum_{i\in A} w_iw(A)=∑i∈A​wi​.

Let F:2V→RF: 2^V \to \mathbb{R}F:2V→R be a submodular function of the form:

F=∑i=1rFiF(∅)=0\begin{align*} F &= \sum_{i=1}^r F_i\\ F(\emptyset) &= 0 \end{align*} FF(∅)​=i=1∑r​Fi​=0​

where each fif_ifi​ is a simple submodular function.

Additionally, we assume minimizing Fi+wF_i+wFi​+w is easy, i.e., there exists efficient oracles to find the minimizer of Fi+wF_i + wFi​+w for each iii and w∈Rnw\in \mathbb R^nw∈Rn.

We want to minimize FFF.

We pivot to the minimization of the Lovász extension fff.

Let fff be the Lovász extension of FFF written as the support function of the base polytope B(F)B(F)B(F):

f(x)=max⁡w∈B(F)⟨w,x⟩f(x) = \max_{w\in B(F)} \langle w, x \rangle f(x)=w∈B(F)max​⟨w,x⟩

where B(F)={w∈Rn:w(A)≤F(A),∀A⊆V,w(V)=F(V)}B(F) = \{w\in \mathbb{R}^n: w(A) \leq F(A), \forall A\subseteq V, w(V)=F(V)\}B(F)={w∈Rn:w(A)≤F(A),∀A⊆V,w(V)=F(V)}.

And let fif_ifi​ be the Lovász extension of FiF_iFi​, BiB_iBi​ be the base polytope of FiF_iFi​.

The paper considers a proximal version of the problem:

min⁡x∈Rnf(x)+12∥x∥2≡min⁡x∈Rn∑i=1rfi(x)+12r∥x∥2\min_{x\in \mathbb{R}^n} f(x) + \frac{1}{2}\|x\|^2 \equiv \min_{x\in \mathbb{R}^n} \sum_{i=1}^r f_i(x) + \frac{1}{2r}\|x\|^2 x∈Rnmin​f(x)+21​∥x∥2≡x∈Rnmin​i=1∑r​fi​(x)+2r1​∥x∥2

Given an optimal solution xxx to the proximal problem, one can obtain an optimal solution to the discrete problem by thresholding xxx at 000; more precisely, the optimal solution to the discrete problem is given by A={i:xi≥0}A = \{i: x_i \geq 0\}A={i:xi​≥0}.

Lemma 1

The dual of the proximal problem is given by:

max⁡y(1)∈B1,…,y(r)∈Br−12∥∑i=1ry(i)∥2.\max_{y^(1)\in B_1, \ldots, y^(r)\in B_r} -\frac{1}{2}\|\sum_{i=1}^r y^{(i)}\|^2. y(1)∈B1​,…,y(r)∈Br​max​−21​∥i=1∑r​y(i)∥2.

The primal and dual variables are related by:

x=−∑i=1ry(i).x = -\sum_{i=1}^r y^{(i)}. x=−i=1∑r​y(i).

Application on Densest Subgraph Problem

To see the definition, please refer to the Densest Subgraph Problem post.

The quadratic formulation of DDS problem is defined as follows:

QP(c):min⁡c⋅∑u∈V(∑(u,v)∈Eαu,v)2+1c⋅∑v∈V(∑(u,v)∈Eβv,u)2s.t.αu,v+βv,u=1,∀(u,v)∈Eαu,v,βv,u≥0∀(u,v)∈E\begin{align*} \mathsf{QP}(c):&&\min&&\sqrt c \cdot \sum_{u\in V}\left(\sum_{(u,v) \in E}\alpha_{u,v}\right)^2+\frac 1{\sqrt c} \cdot & \sum_{v\in V}\left(\sum_{(u,v) \in E}\beta_{v,u}\right)^2 \\ && \text{s.t.}&&\alpha_{u,v}+\beta_{v,u} &=1,&& \forall (u,v) \in E\\ && &&\alpha_{u,v},\beta_{v,u} &\geq 0 && \forall (u,v) \in E \end{align*} QP(c):​​mins.t.​​c​⋅u∈V∑​​(u,v)∈E∑​αu,v​​2+c​1​⋅αu,v​+βv,u​αu,v​,βv,u​​v∈V∑​​(u,v)∈E∑​βv,u​​2=1,≥0​​∀(u,v)∈E∀(u,v)∈E​

The dual of such quadratic program is formulated as follows:

Lagrangian relaxation

L=c∑u∈V(∑(u,v)∈Eαu,v)2+1c∑v∈V(∑(u,v)∈Eβv,u)2+∑(u,v)∈Eλu,v(1−αu,v−βv,u)−∑(u,v)∈Eρu,vαu,v−∑(u,v)∈Eσv,uβv,u\begin{align*} L = & \sqrt{c} \sum_{u\in V}\left(\sum_{(u,v) \in E}\alpha_{u,v}\right)^2 + \frac{1}{\sqrt{c}} \sum_{v\in V}\left(\sum_{(u,v) \in E}\beta_{v,u}\right)^2 \\ & + \sum_{(u,v) \in E} \lambda_{u,v}(1 - \alpha_{u,v} - \beta_{v,u}) \\ & - \sum_{(u,v) \in E} \rho_{u,v} \alpha_{u,v} - \sum_{(u,v) \in E} \sigma_{v,u} \beta_{v,u} \end{align*} L=​c​u∈V∑​​(u,v)∈E∑​αu,v​​2+c​1​v∈V∑​​(u,v)∈E∑​βv,u​​2+(u,v)∈E∑​λu,v​(1−αu,v​−βv,u​)−(u,v)∈E∑​ρu,v​αu,v​−(u,v)∈E∑​σv,u​βv,u​​

Now consider the KKT conditions:

KKT Conditions

Stationarity Conditions

∂L∂αu,v=2c∑(u,s)∈Eαu,s−λu,v−ρu,v=0∂L∂βv,u=2c∑(t,v)∈Eβv,t−λu,v−σv,u=0\begin{align*} \frac{\partial L}{\partial \alpha_{u,v}} &= 2\sqrt{c} \sum_{(u,s) \in E}\alpha_{u,s} - \lambda_{u,v} - \rho_{u,v} = 0 \\ \frac{\partial L}{\partial \beta_{v,u}} &= \frac{2}{\sqrt{c}} \sum_{(t,v) \in E}\beta_{v,t} - \lambda_{u,v} - \sigma_{v,u} = 0 \end{align*} ∂αu,v​∂L​∂βv,u​∂L​​=2c​(u,s)∈E∑​αu,s​−λu,v​−ρu,v​=0=c​2​(t,v)∈E∑​βv,t​−λu,v​−σv,u​=0​

Define:

wα(u)=∑(u,v)∈Eαu,v,wβ(v)=∑(u,v)∈Eβv,uw_{\alpha}(u) = \sum_{(u,v) \in E}\alpha_{u,v}, \quad w_{\beta}(v) = \sum_{(u,v) \in E}\beta_{v,u} wα​(u)=(u,v)∈E∑​αu,v​,wβ​(v)=(u,v)∈E∑​βv,u​

Then:

2cwα(u)−λu,v−ρu,v=02cwβ(v)−λu,v−σv,u=0\begin{align*} 2\sqrt{c} w_{\alpha}(u) - \lambda_{u,v} - \rho_{u,v} &= 0\\ \frac{2}{\sqrt{c}} w_{\beta}(v) - \lambda_{u,v} - \sigma_{v,u} &= 0 \end{align*} 2c​wα​(u)−λu,v​−ρu,v​c​2​wβ​(v)−λu,v​−σv,u​​=0=0​

⇒{λu,v+ρu,v=2c∑(u,s)∈Eαu,sλu,v+σv,u=2c∑(t,v)∈Eβv,t\begin{align*} \Rightarrow \begin{cases} \lambda_{u,v} + \rho_{u,v} &= 2\sqrt{c} \sum_{(u,s) \in E}\alpha_{u,s}\\ \lambda_{u,v} + \sigma_{v,u} &= \frac{2}{\sqrt{c}} \sum_{(t,v) \in E}\beta_{v,t} \end{cases} \end{align*} ⇒{λu,v​+ρu,v​λu,v​+σv,u​​=2c​∑(u,s)∈E​αu,s​=c​2​∑(t,v)∈E​βv,t​​​

Primal Feasibility Conditions

αu,v+βv,u=1,∀(u,v)∈Eαu,v,βv,u≥0,∀(u,v)∈E\begin{align*} \alpha_{u,v} + \beta_{v,u} &= 1, && \forall (u,v) \in E \\ \alpha_{u,v}, \beta_{v,u} &\geq 0, && \forall (u,v) \in E \end{align*} αu,v​+βv,u​αu,v​,βv,u​​=1,≥0,​​∀(u,v)∈E∀(u,v)∈E​

Dual Feasibility Conditions

ρu,v≥0,∀(u,v)∈Eσv,u≥0,∀(u,v)∈E\begin{align*} \rho_{u,v} &\geq 0, && \forall (u,v) \in E \\ \sigma_{v,u} &\geq 0, && \forall (u,v) \in E \end{align*} ρu,v​σv,u​​≥0,≥0,​​∀(u,v)∈E∀(u,v)∈E​

Complementary Slackness Conditions

ρu,v⋅αu,v=0,∀(u,v)∈Eσv,u⋅βv,u=0,∀(u,v)∈E\begin{align*} \rho_{u,v} \cdot \alpha_{u,v} &= 0, && \forall (u,v) \in E \\ \sigma_{v,u} \cdot \beta_{v,u} &= 0, && \forall (u,v) \in E \end{align*} ρu,v​⋅αu,v​σv,u​⋅βv,u​​=0,=0,​​∀(u,v)∈E∀(u,v)∈E​

Analysis & Simplification

From the stationarity conditions, we notice that for any vertex uuu, the quantity 2c∑(u,s)∈Eαu,s2\sqrt{c} \sum_{(u,s) \in E}\alpha_{u,s}2c​∑(u,s)∈E​αu,s​ must be equal to λu,v+ρu,v\lambda_{u,v} + \rho_{u,v}λu,v​+ρu,v​ for all edges (u,v)(u,v)(u,v) incident to uuu. This gives us:

λu,v1+ρu,v1=λu,v2+ρu,v2=⋯\lambda_{u,v_1} + \rho_{u,v_1} = \lambda_{u,v_2} + \rho_{u,v_2} = \cdots λu,v1​​+ρu,v1​​=λu,v2​​+ρu,v2​​=⋯

for all edges (u,v1),(u,v2),…(u,v_1), (u,v_2), \ldots(u,v1​),(u,v2​),… incident to vertex uuu.

Similarly, for any vertex vvv:

λu1,v+σv,u1=λu2,v+σv,u2=⋯\lambda_{u_1,v} + \sigma_{v,u_1} = \lambda_{u_2,v} + \sigma_{v,u_2} = \cdots λu1​,v​+σv,u1​​=λu2​,v​+σv,u2​​=⋯

Let us define:

xu:=2c∑(u,s)∈Eαu,s,yv:=2c∑(t,v)∈Eβv,tx_u := 2\sqrt{c} \sum_{(u,s) \in E}\alpha_{u,s}, \quad y_v := \frac{2}{\sqrt{c}} \sum_{(t,v) \in E}\beta_{v,t} xu​:=2c​(u,s)∈E∑​αu,s​,yv​:=c​2​(t,v)∈E∑​βv,t​

Then we have:

λu,v+ρu,v=xu,λu,v+σv,u=yv\lambda_{u,v} + \rho_{u,v} = x_u, \quad \lambda_{u,v} + \sigma_{v,u} = y_v λu,v​+ρu,v​=xu​,λu,v​+σv,u​=yv​

Substituting stationarity conditions back to Lagrangian:

inf⁡α,β,wL(α,β,w,λ,ρ,σ)=c∑u∈V(∑(u,v)∈Eαu,v)2+1c∑v∈V(∑(u,v)∈Eβv,u)2+∑(u,v)∈Eλu,v(1−αu,v−βv,u)−∑(u,v)∈Eρu,vαu,v−∑(u,v)∈Eσv,uβv,u=c∑u∈V(∑(u,v)∈Eαu,v)2+1c∑v∈V(∑(u,v)∈Eβv,u)2+∑(u,v)∈Eλu,v−∑(u,v)∈E(λu,v+ρu,v)αu,v−∑(u,v)∈E(λu,v+σv,u)βv,u=c∑u∈V(∑(u,v)∈Eαu,v)2+1c∑v∈V(∑(u,v)∈Eβv,u)2+∑(u,v)∈Eλu,v−∑(u,v)∈E(2c∑(u,s)∈Eαu,s)αu,v−∑(u,v)∈E(2c∑(t,v)∈Eβv,t)βv,u=c∑u∈V(∑(u,v)∈Eαu,v)2+1c∑v∈V(∑(u,v)∈Eβv,u)2+∑(u,v)∈Eλu,v−2c∑u∈V(∑(u,v)∈Eαu,v)2−2c∑v∈V(∑(u,v)∈Eβv,u)2=−c∑u∈V(∑(u,v)∈Eαu,v)2−1c∑v∈V(∑(u,v)∈Eβv,u)2+∑(u,v)∈Eλu,v=−14c∑u∈Vxu2−c4∑v∈Vyv2+∑(u,v)∈Eλu,v\begin{align*} \inf_{\alpha,\beta,w}L(\alpha,\beta,w,\lambda,\rho,\sigma) = & \sqrt{c} \sum_{u\in V}\left(\sum_{(u,v) \in E}\alpha_{u,v}\right)^2 + \frac{1}{\sqrt{c}} \sum_{v\in V}\left(\sum_{(u,v) \in E}\beta_{v,u}\right)^2 \\ & + \sum_{(u,v) \in E} \lambda_{u,v}(1 - \alpha_{u,v} - \beta_{v,u}) \\ & - \sum_{(u,v) \in E} \rho_{u,v} \alpha_{u,v} - \sum_{(u,v) \in E} \sigma_{v,u} \beta_{v,u}\\ = & \sqrt{c} \sum_{u\in V}\left(\sum_{(u,v) \in E}\alpha_{u,v}\right)^2 + \frac{1}{\sqrt{c}} \sum_{v\in V}\left(\sum_{(u,v) \in E}\beta_{v,u}\right)^2 \\ & + \sum_{(u,v) \in E} \lambda_{u,v} \\ & - \sum_{(u,v) \in E} (\lambda_{u,v} + \rho_{u,v}) \alpha_{u,v} - \sum_{(u,v) \in E} (\lambda_{u,v} + \sigma_{v,u}) \beta_{v,u}\\ = & \sqrt{c} \sum_{u\in V}\left(\sum_{(u,v) \in E}\alpha_{u,v}\right)^2 + \frac{1}{\sqrt{c}} \sum_{v\in V}\left(\sum_{(u,v) \in E}\beta_{v,u}\right)^2 \\ & + \sum_{(u,v) \in E} \lambda_{u,v} - \sum_{(u,v) \in E} \left(2\sqrt{c} \sum_{(u,s) \in E}\alpha_{u,s}\right) \alpha_{u,v} \\ & - \sum_{(u,v) \in E} \left(\frac{2}{\sqrt{c}} \sum_{(t,v) \in E}\beta_{v,t}\right) \beta_{v,u} \\ = & \sqrt{c} \sum_{u\in V}\left(\sum_{(u,v) \in E}\alpha_{u,v}\right)^2 + \frac{1}{\sqrt{c}} \sum_{v\in V}\left(\sum_{(u,v) \in E}\beta_{v,u}\right)^2 \\ & + \sum_{(u,v) \in E} \lambda_{u,v} - 2\sqrt{c} \sum_{u \in V} \left(\sum_{(u,v) \in E}\alpha_{u,v}\right)^2 \\ & - \frac{2}{\sqrt{c}} \sum_{v \in V} \left(\sum_{(u,v) \in E}\beta_{v,u}\right)^2 \\ = & -\sqrt{c} \sum_{u\in V}\left(\sum_{(u,v) \in E}\alpha_{u,v}\right)^2 - \frac{1}{\sqrt{c}} \sum_{v\in V}\left(\sum_{(u,v) \in E}\beta_{v,u}\right)^2 \\ & + \sum_{(u,v) \in E} \lambda_{u,v} \\ = & -\frac{1}{4\sqrt{c}} \sum_{u\in V} x_u^2 - \frac{\sqrt{c}}{4} \sum_{v\in V} y_v^2 + \sum_{(u,v) \in E} \lambda_{u,v} \end{align*} α,β,winf​L(α,β,w,λ,ρ,σ)======​c​u∈V∑​​(u,v)∈E∑​αu,v​​2+c​1​v∈V∑​​(u,v)∈E∑​βv,u​​2+(u,v)∈E∑​λu,v​(1−αu,v​−βv,u​)−(u,v)∈E∑​ρu,v​αu,v​−(u,v)∈E∑​σv,u​βv,u​c​u∈V∑​​(u,v)∈E∑​αu,v​​2+c​1​v∈V∑​​(u,v)∈E∑​βv,u​​2+(u,v)∈E∑​λu,v​−(u,v)∈E∑​(λu,v​+ρu,v​)αu,v​−(u,v)∈E∑​(λu,v​+σv,u​)βv,u​c​u∈V∑​​(u,v)∈E∑​αu,v​​2+c​1​v∈V∑​​(u,v)∈E∑​βv,u​​2+(u,v)∈E∑​λu,v​−(u,v)∈E∑​​2c​(u,s)∈E∑​αu,s​​αu,v​−(u,v)∈E∑​​c​2​(t,v)∈E∑​βv,t​​βv,u​c​u∈V∑​​(u,v)∈E∑​αu,v​​2+c​1​v∈V∑​​(u,v)∈E∑​βv,u​​2+(u,v)∈E∑​λu,v​−2c​u∈V∑​​(u,v)∈E∑​αu,v​​2−c​2​v∈V∑​​(u,v)∈E∑​βv,u​​2−c​u∈V∑​​(u,v)∈E∑​αu,v​​2−c​1​v∈V∑​​(u,v)∈E∑​βv,u​​2+(u,v)∈E∑​λu,v​−4c​1​u∈V∑​xu2​−4c​​v∈V∑​yv2​+(u,v)∈E∑​λu,v​​

To maximize the dual objective, we want to maximize λu,v\lambda_{u,v}λu,v​ which means minimizing ρu,v+σv,u\rho_{u,v} + \sigma_{v,u}ρu,v​+σv,u​ subject to:

  • ρu,v,σv,u≥0\rho_{u,v}, \sigma_{v,u} \geq 0ρu,v​,σv,u​≥0
  • λu,v=xu−ρu,v=yv−σv,u\lambda_{u,v} = x_u - \rho_{u,v} = y_v - \sigma_{v,u}λu,v​=xu​−ρu,v​=yv​−σv,u​

This gives us ρu,v−σv,u=xu−yv\rho_{u,v} - \sigma_{v,u} = x_u - y_vρu,v​−σv,u​=xu​−yv​.

Case 1: If xu≥yvx_u \geq y_vxu​≥yv​, set σv,u=0\sigma_{v,u} = 0σv,u​=0 and ρu,v=xu−yv≥0\rho_{u,v} = x_u - y_v \geq 0ρu,v​=xu​−yv​≥0. Then λu,v=yv\lambda_{u,v} = y_vλu,v​=yv​.

Case 2: If xu≤yvx_u \leq y_vxu​≤yv​, set ρu,v=0\rho_{u,v} = 0ρu,v​=0 and σv,u=yv−xu≥0\sigma_{v,u} = y_v - x_u \geq 0σv,u​=yv​−xu​≥0. Then λu,v=xu\lambda_{u,v} = x_uλu,v​=xu​.

Therefore: λu,v=min⁡(xu,yv)\lambda_{u,v} = \min(x_u, y_v)λu,v​=min(xu​,yv​).

So the dual objective function can be simplified to:

DQP(c)=max⁡x,y−14c∑u∈Vxu2−c4∑v∈Vyv2+∑(u,v)∈Emin⁡(xu,yv)\begin{align*} \mathsf{DQP}(c) &= \max_{x,y} -\frac{1}{4\sqrt{c}} \sum_{u\in V} x_u^2 - \frac{\sqrt{c}}{4} \sum_{v\in V} y_v^2 + \sum_{(u,v) \in E} \min(x_u, y_v) \end{align*} DQP(c)​=x,ymax​−4c​1​u∈V∑​xu2​−4c​​v∈V∑​yv2​+(u,v)∈E∑​min(xu​,yv​)​

And the constraints are given by the primal feasibility conditions, which is equivalent to:

12c∑u∈Vxu+c2∑v∈Vyv=∣E∣xu,yv≥0,∀u∈V,v∈V\begin{align*} \frac{1}{2\sqrt{c}}\sum_{u \in V} x_u + \frac{\sqrt{c}}{2}\sum_{v \in V} y_v = |E| \\ x_u, y_v \geq 0, \quad \forall u \in V, v \in V \end{align*} 2c​1​u∈V∑​xu​+2c​​v∈V∑​yv​=∣E∣xu​,yv​≥0,∀u∈V,v∈V​

Because a valid solution of primal can be constructed by using flow theory.

Dual Quadratic Program

Set new x=(x2,y2)x=(\frac{x}{2}, \frac{y}{2})x=(2x​,2y​), we can rewrite the dual quadratic program as follows:

DQP(c):min⁡x∈R2n12xTWx−∑(u,v)∈Emin⁡(xu,xn+v)s.t. aTx=∣E∣xu≥0,∀u∈Vwhere W=[1cIn00cIn],a⃗=[1c,1c,…,1c,c,c,…,c]T\begin{align*} \mathsf{DQP}(c):&\min_{x\in \mathbb R^{2n}} \frac{1}{2}x^TWx - \sum_{(u,v)\in E}\min(x_u,x_{n+v})\\ &\text{s.t. } a^Tx = |E| \\ &\quad\quad\quad x_u \geq 0, \quad \forall u \in V\\ &\text{where } W=\begin{bmatrix} \frac{1}{\sqrt c}I_n & 0 \\ 0 & \sqrt{c}I_n \end{bmatrix} , \quad \vec{a} = [\frac{1}{\sqrt{c}}, \frac{1}{\sqrt{c}}, \ldots, \frac{1}{\sqrt{c}},\sqrt{c}, \sqrt{c}, \ldots, \sqrt{c}]^T \end{align*} DQP(c):​x∈R2nmin​21​xTWx−(u,v)∈E∑​min(xu​,xn+v​)s.t. aTx=∣E∣xu​≥0,∀u∈Vwhere W=[c​1​In​0​0c​In​​],a=[c​1​,c​1​,…,c​1​,c​,c​,…,c​]T​

Submodular Function Representation

Let define the submodular function F:2V∐V→RF:2^{V\coprod V}\to \mathbb RF:2V∐V→R as follows:

F(S,T)=∑(u,v)∈EFu,v(S,T)=−∣E(S,T)∣F(S,T) = \sum_{(u,v)\in E} F_{u,v}(S,T) = -|E(S,T)| F(S,T)=(u,v)∈E∑​Fu,v​(S,T)=−∣E(S,T)∣

Fu,v(S,T)F_{u,v}(S,T)Fu,v​(S,T) is defined as follows:

Fu,v(S,T)={0if u∉S and v∉T0if u∈S and v∉T0if u∉S and v∈T−1if u∈S and v∈TF_{u,v}(S,T) = \begin{cases} 0 & \text{if } u\notin S \text{ and } v\notin T \\ 0 & \text{if } u\in S \text{ and } v\notin T \\ 0 & \text{if } u\notin S \text{ and } v\in T\\ -1 & \text{if } u\in S \text{ and } v\in T \end{cases} Fu,v​(S,T)=⎩⎨⎧​000−1​if u∈/S and v∈/Tif u∈S and v∈/Tif u∈/S and v∈Tif u∈S and v∈T​

The base polytope B(Fu,v)B(F_{u,v})B(Fu,v​) is defined as follows:

B(Fu,v)={w∈RV∐V:w(S,T)≤F(S,T),∀S⊆V,T⊆V,w(V,V)=F(V,V)}B(F_{u,v}) = \{w\in \mathbb{R}^{V\coprod V}: w(S,T) \leq F(S,T), \forall S\subseteq V, T\subseteq V, w(V,V)=F(V,V)\} B(Fu,v​)={w∈RV∐V:w(S,T)≤F(S,T),∀S⊆V,T⊆V,w(V,V)=F(V,V)}

Obviously we have wj=0w_{j}=0wj​=0 for all j≠u or v+nj\neq u \text{ or } {v+n}j=u or v+n. (Here use v+nv+nv+n to denote the vertex corresponding to vvv in the second copy of VVV.)

And wu+wv+n=−1w_{u}+w_{v+n} = -1wu​+wv+n​=−1.

the Lovász extension of Fu,vF_{u,v}Fu,v​ is given by:

fu,v(x)=max⁡w∈B(Fu,v)⟨w,x⟩f_{u,v}(x) = \max_{w\in B(F_{u,v})} \langle w, x \rangle fu,v​(x)=w∈B(Fu,v​)max​⟨w,x⟩

which just equals to −min⁡(xu,xn+v)-\min(x_u, x_{n+v})−min(xu​,xn+v​).

Thus, with aTxa^TxaTx normalized from ∣E∣|E|∣E∣ to 222,

the dual quadratic program can be rewritten as:

DQP(c):min⁡x∈R2n12xTWx+∑(u,v)∈Efu,v(x)s.t. aTx=2xu,yv≥0,∀u∈V,v∈Vwhere W=[1cIn00cIn],a⃗=[1c,1c,…,1c,c,c,…,c]T\begin{align*} \mathsf{DQP}(c):&\min_{x\in \mathbb R^{2n}} \frac{1}{2}x^TWx + \sum_{(u,v)\in E} f_{u,v}(x)\\ &\text{s.t. } a^Tx = 2 \\ &\quad\quad\quad x_u, y_v \geq 0, \quad \forall u \in V, v \in V \\ &\text{where } W=\begin{bmatrix} \frac{1}{\sqrt c}I_n & 0 \\ 0 & \sqrt{c}I_n \end{bmatrix}, \quad \vec{a} = [\frac{1}{\sqrt{c}}, \frac{1}{\sqrt{c}}, \ldots, \frac{1}{\sqrt{c}},\sqrt{c}, \sqrt{c}, \ldots, \sqrt{c}]^T \end{align*} DQP(c):​x∈R2nmin​21​xTWx+(u,v)∈E∑​fu,v​(x)s.t. aTx=2xu​,yv​≥0,∀u∈V,v∈Vwhere W=[c​1​In​0​0c​In​​],a=[c​1​,c​1​,…,c​1​,c​,c​,…,c​]T​

Another Derivation

Just ignore the quadratic term, we can rewrite the dual quadratic program as a ratio linear program (RLP):

RLP(c):max⁡x∈R2n∑(u,v)∈Emin⁡(xu,xn+v)s.t. aTx=2xu,yv≥0,∀u∈V,v∈Vwhere a⃗=[1c,1c,…,1c,c,c,…,c]T\begin{align*} \mathsf{RLP}(c):&\max_{x\in \mathbb R^{2n}} \sum_{(u,v)\in E}\min(x_u,x_{n+v})\\ &\text{s.t. } a^Tx = 2 \\ &\quad\quad\quad x_u, y_v \geq 0, \quad \forall u \in V, v \in V \\ &\text{where } \vec{a} = [\frac{1}{\sqrt{c}}, \frac{1}{\sqrt{c}}, \ldots, \frac{1}{\sqrt{c}},\sqrt{c}, \sqrt{c}, \ldots, \sqrt{c}]^T \end{align*} RLP(c):​x∈R2nmax​(u,v)∈E∑​min(xu​,xn+v​)s.t. aTx=2xu​,yv​≥0,∀u∈V,v∈Vwhere a=[c​1​,c​1​,…,c​1​,c​,c​,…,c​]T​

Let’s introduce the definition of c-biased density:

ρc(S,T)=2cc′c+c′∣E(S,T)∣∣S∣∣T∣=2∣E(S,T)∣1c∣S∣+c∣T∣where c′=∣S∣∣T∣\begin{gather*} \rho_c(S,T) = \frac{2 \sqrt c \sqrt {c'}}{c+c'} \frac{|E(S,T)|}{\sqrt{|S||T|}}=\frac{2|E(S,T)|}{\frac{1}{\sqrt c} |S|+ \sqrt c |T|}\\ \text{where } c' = \frac{|S|}{|T|} \end{gather*} ρc​(S,T)=c+c′2c​c′​​∣S∣∣T∣​∣E(S,T)∣​=c​1​∣S∣+c​∣T∣2∣E(S,T)∣​where c′=∣T∣∣S∣​​

And the c-biased DDS is defined as the subgraph G(S,T) such that ρc(S,T)\rho_c(S,T)ρc​(S,T) is maximized.

We have the following theorem:

Theorem 1

The optimal value of RLP(c)\mathsf{RLP}(c)RLP(c), OPT(RLP(c))=ρc∗(S,T)\text{OPT}({\mathsf{RLP}(c)})=\rho^*_c(S,T)OPT(RLP(c))=ρc∗​(S,T) and the optimal solution can be recovered by thresholding.

Proof

First, we show that OPT(RLP(c))≥ρc∗(S,T)\text{OPT}({\mathsf{RLP}(c)})\geq \rho^*_c(S,T)OPT(RLP(c))≥ρc∗​(S,T).

For any vertex sets S⊆V,T⊆VS \subseteq V, T \subseteq VS⊆V,T⊆V, consider the feasible solution to RLP:

xu=αx_u = \alphaxu​=α for u∈Su \in Su∈S, xu=0x_u = 0xu​=0 for u∉Su \notin Su∈/S

xn+v=βx_{n+v} = \betaxn+v​=β for v∈Tv \in Tv∈T, xn+v=0x_{n+v} = 0xn+v​=0 for v∉Tv \notin Tv∈/T

The constraint gives us:

1c∣S∣⋅α+c∣T∣⋅β=2\frac{1}{\sqrt{c}}|S| \cdot \alpha + \sqrt{c}|T| \cdot \beta = 2 c​1​∣S∣⋅α+c​∣T∣⋅β=2

The objective value is:

∑(u,v)∈Emin⁡(xu,xn+v)=∣E(S,T)∣⋅min⁡(α,β)\sum_{(u,v) \in E} \min(x_u, x_{n+v}) = |E(S,T)| \cdot \min(\alpha, \beta) (u,v)∈E∑​min(xu​,xn+v​)=∣E(S,T)∣⋅min(α,β)

To maximize this, we want to maximize min⁡(α,β)\min(\alpha, \beta)min(α,β) subject to the constraint.

If α=β\alpha = \betaα=β, then: α=21c∣S∣+c∣T∣\alpha = \frac{2}{\frac{1}{\sqrt{c}}|S| + \sqrt{c}|T|}α=c​1​∣S∣+c​∣T∣2​

Objective = ∣E(S,T)∣⋅21c∣S∣+c∣T∣|E(S,T)| \cdot \frac{2}{\frac{1}{\sqrt{c}}|S| + \sqrt{c}|T|}∣E(S,T)∣⋅c​1​∣S∣+c​∣T∣2​

This can be rewritten as:

2∣E(S,T)∣1c∣S∣+c∣T∣=ρc(S,T)\frac{2|E(S,T)|}{\frac{1}{\sqrt{c}}|S| + \sqrt{c}|T|} = \rho_c(S,T) c​1​∣S∣+c​∣T∣2∣E(S,T)∣​=ρc​(S,T)

Therefore: OPT(RLP(c))≥max⁡S,Tρc(S,T)\text{OPT}({\mathsf{RLP}(c)}) \geq \max_{S,T} \rho_c(S,T)OPT(RLP(c))≥maxS,T​ρc​(S,T)

Now we show that OPT(RLP(c))≤max⁡S,Tρc(S,T)\text{OPT}({\mathsf{RLP}(c)}) \leq \max_{S,T} \rho_c(S,T)OPT(RLP(c))≤maxS,T​ρc​(S,T).

The LP objective can be rewritten as:

∑(u,v)∈Emin⁡(xu∗,yv∗)=∑(u,v)∈E∫0∞1[xu∗≥t and yv∗≥t] dt\sum_{(u,v) \in E} \min(x^*_u, y^*_v) = \sum_{(u,v) \in E} \int_0^{\infty} \mathbf{1}[x^*_u \geq t \text{ and } y^*_v \geq t] \, dt (u,v)∈E∑​min(xu∗​,yv∗​)=(u,v)∈E∑​∫0∞​1[xu∗​≥t and yv∗​≥t]dt

For each threshold t≥0t \geq 0t≥0, define:

  • St={u∈V:xu∗≥t}S_t = \{u \in V : x^*_u \geq t\}St​={u∈V:xu∗​≥t} (vertices in first part with value ≥ t)
  • Tt={v∈V:yv∗≥t}T_t = \{v \in V : y^*_v \geq t\}Tt​={v∈V:yv∗​≥t} (vertices in second part with value ≥ t)

Then the number of edges between StS_tSt​ and TtT_tTt​ is given by:

∑(u,v)∈E1[xu∗≥t and yv∗≥t]=∣E(St,Tt)∣\sum_{(u,v) \in E} \mathbf{1}[x^*_u \geq t \text{ and } y^*_v \geq t] = |E(S_t, T_t)| (u,v)∈E∑​1[xu∗​≥t and yv∗​≥t]=∣E(St​,Tt​)∣

Consider the constraint:

1c∑uxu∗+c∑vyv∗=1c∑u∫0∞1[xu∗≥t] dt+c∑v∫0∞1[yv∗≥t] dt=∫0∞(1c∣St∣+c∣Tt∣)dt\begin{align*} \frac{1}{\sqrt{c}}\sum_{u} x^*_u + \sqrt{c}\sum_{v} y^*_v &= \frac{1}{\sqrt{c}}\sum_{u} \int_0^{\infty} \mathbf{1}[x^*_u \geq t] \, dt + \sqrt{c}\sum_{v} \int_0^{\infty} \mathbf{1}[y^*_v \geq t] \, dt\\ &= \int_0^{\infty} \left( \frac{1}{\sqrt{c}}|S_t| + \sqrt{c}|T_t| \right) dt \end{align*} c​1​u∑​xu∗​+c​v∑​yv∗​​=c​1​u∑​∫0∞​1[xu∗​≥t]dt+c​v∑​∫0∞​1[yv∗​≥t]dt=∫0∞​(c​1​∣St​∣+c​∣Tt​∣)dt​

So

LP objective2=∫0∞∣E(St,Tt)∣ dt∫0∞(1c∣St∣+c∣Tt∣)dt\frac{\text{LP objective}}{2} = \frac{\int_0^{\infty} |E(S_t, T_t)| \, dt}{\int_0^{\infty} \left( \frac{1}{\sqrt{c}}|S_t| + \sqrt{c}|T_t| \right) dt} 2LP objective​=∫0∞​(c​1​∣St​∣+c​∣Tt​∣)dt∫0∞​∣E(St​,Tt​)∣dt​

By averaging principle:

∫g(t)dt∫h(t)dt≤max⁡tg(t)h(t)\frac{\int g(t) dt}{\int h(t) dt} \leq \max_t \frac{g(t)}{h(t)} ∫h(t)dt∫g(t)dt​≤tmax​h(t)g(t)​

We get:

LP objective2≤max⁡t≥0∣E(St,Tt)∣1c∣St∣+c∣Tt∣\frac{\text{LP objective}}{2} \leq \max_{t \geq 0} \frac{|E(S_t, T_t)|}{\frac{1}{\sqrt{c}}|S_t| + \sqrt{c}|T_t|} 2LP objective​≤t≥0max​c​1​∣St​∣+c​∣Tt​∣∣E(St​,Tt​)∣​

Thus:

OPT(RLP(c))≤max⁡S,Tρc(S,T)\text{OPT}({\mathsf{RLP}(c)}) \leq \max_{S,T} \rho_c(S,T) OPT(RLP(c))≤S,Tmax​ρc​(S,T)

This completes the proof of Theorem 1.

And DQP\text{DQP}DQP can be considered as a proximal version of RLP\text{RLP}RLP.

Key Sets and Definitions

Feasible Set:
Y=∏i=1rB(Fi)=B(F1)×B(F2)×⋯×B(Fr)Y = \prod_{i=1}^r B(F_i) = B(F_1) \times B(F_2) \times \cdots \times B(F_r)Y=∏i=1r​B(Fi​)=B(F1​)×B(F2​)×⋯×B(Fr​)

Null Space:
Q={y∈R2nr:Sy=0}={y∈R2nr:∑i=1rWy(i)=0}Q = \{y \in \mathbb{R}^{2nr} : Sy = 0\} = \left\{y \in \mathbb{R}^{2nr} : \sum_{i=1}^r W y^{(i)} = 0\right\}Q={y∈R2nr:Sy=0}={y∈R2nr:∑i=1r​Wy(i)=0}

Optimal Solution Set:
E={y∈Y:g(y)=min⁡z∈Yg(z)}E = \{y \in Y : g(y) = \min_{z \in Y} g(z)\}E={y∈Y:g(y)=minz∈Y​g(z)}

Alternative Characterization of EEE:
E={y∈Y:d(y,Q)=d(Y,Q)}E = \{y \in Y : d(y, Q) = d(Y, Q)\}E={y∈Y:d(y,Q)=d(Y,Q)}

where d(y,Q)=min⁡z∈Q∥y−z∥d(y, Q) = \min_{z \in Q} \|y - z\|d(y,Q)=minz∈Q​∥y−z∥ and d(Y,Q)=min⁡y∈Yd(y,Q)d(Y, Q) = \min_{y \in Y} d(y, Q)d(Y,Q)=miny∈Y​d(y,Q).

Geometric Interpretation:

  • EEE represents the set of points in the feasible region YYY that are closest to satisfying the constraint Sy=0Sy = 0Sy=0
  • Points in EEE are optimal solutions to our proximal optimization problem
  • The set EEE connects to optimal solutions of the original discrete problem via thresholding

Geometric Bound from Theorem 2 Analogue

We need the relationship between function values and distances.

Key Geometric Relationship: For our specific objective function g(y)=r∥Sy∥2g(y) = r\|Sy\|^2g(y)=r∥Sy∥2, we have:

g(yℓ)=g(y∗)+⟨∇g(y∗),yℓ−y∗⟩+∫01⟨∇g(y∗+t(yℓ−y∗))−∇g(y∗),yℓ−y∗⟩dtg(y_\ell) = g(y^*) + \langle\nabla g(y^*), y_\ell - y^*\rangle + \int_0^1 \langle\nabla g(y^* + t(y_\ell - y^*)) - \nabla g(y^*), y_\ell - y^*\rangle dt g(yℓ​)=g(y∗)+⟨∇g(y∗),yℓ​−y∗⟩+∫01​⟨∇g(y∗+t(yℓ​−y∗))−∇g(y∗),yℓ​−y∗⟩dt

This uses the fundamental theorem of calculus. For ϕ(t)=g(y∗+t(yℓ−y∗))\phi(t) = g(y^* + t(y_\ell - y^*))ϕ(t)=g(y∗+t(yℓ​−y∗)):

g(yℓ)−g(y∗)=∫01ϕ′(t)dt=∫01⟨∇g(y∗+t(yℓ−y∗)),yℓ−y∗⟩dtg(y_\ell) - g(y^*) = \int_0^1 \phi'(t) dt = \int_0^1 \langle\nabla g(y^* + t(y_\ell - y^*)), y_\ell - y^*\rangle dt g(yℓ​)−g(y∗)=∫01​ϕ′(t)dt=∫01​⟨∇g(y∗+t(yℓ​−y∗)),yℓ​−y∗⟩dt

Since ∇g(z)=2rSTSz\nabla g(z) = 2rS^T Sz∇g(z)=2rSTSz:

∇g(y∗+t(yℓ−y∗))−∇g(y∗)=2rSTS⋅t(yℓ−y∗)\nabla g(y^* + t(y_\ell - y^*)) - \nabla g(y^*) = 2rS^T S \cdot t(y_\ell - y^*) ∇g(y∗+t(yℓ​−y∗))−∇g(y∗)=2rSTS⋅t(yℓ​−y∗)

Therefore:

∫01⟨∇g(y∗+t(yℓ−y∗))−∇g(y∗),yℓ−y∗⟩dt=∫012rt∥S(yℓ−y∗)∥2dt=r∥S(yℓ−y∗)∥2\int_0^1 \langle\nabla g(y^* + t(y_\ell - y^*)) - \nabla g(y^*), y_\ell - y^*\rangle dt = \int_0^1 2rt\|S(y_\ell - y^*)\|^2 dt = r\|S(y_\ell - y^*)\|^2 ∫01​⟨∇g(y∗+t(yℓ​−y∗))−∇g(y∗),yℓ​−y∗⟩dt=∫01​2rt∥S(yℓ​−y∗)∥2dt=r∥S(yℓ​−y∗)∥2

Since y∗y^*y∗ is optimal, ⟨∇g(y∗),yℓ−y∗⟩≤0\langle\nabla g(y^*), y_\ell - y^*\rangle \leq 0⟨∇g(y∗),yℓ​−y∗⟩≤0 (first-order optimality condition).

Thus:

g(yℓ)−g(y∗)≥r∥S(yℓ−y∗)∥2g(y_\ell) - g(y^*) \geq r\|S(y_\ell - y^*)\|^2 g(yℓ​)−g(y∗)≥r∥S(yℓ​−y∗)∥2

Applying Theorem 2 Analog

From our Theorem 2 analog:

∥S(yℓ−y∗)∥≥12nr∥yℓ−y∗∥\|S(y_\ell - y^*)\| \geq \frac{1}{2nr} \|y_\ell - y^*\| ∥S(yℓ​−y∗)∥≥2nr1​∥yℓ​−y∗∥

Therefore:

g(yℓ)−g(y∗)≥r∥S(yℓ−y∗)∥2≥r(2nr)2∥yℓ−y∗∥2g(y_\ell) - g(y^*) \geq r\|S(y_\ell - y^*)\|^2 \geq \frac{r}{(2nr)^2} \|y_\ell - y^*\|^2 g(yℓ​)−g(y∗)≥r∥S(yℓ​−y∗)∥2≥(2nr)2r​∥yℓ​−y∗∥2

=14n2r∥yℓ−y∗∥2= \frac{1}{4n^2r} \|y_\ell - y^*\|^2 =4n2r1​∥yℓ​−y∗∥2

Geometric Bound:

∥yℓ−y∗∥2≤4n2r(g(yℓ)−g(y∗))\|y_\ell - y^*\|^2 \leq 4n^2r (g(y_\ell) - g(y^*)) ∥yℓ​−y∗∥2≤4n2r(g(yℓ​)−g(y∗))

Single Epoch Analysis

Consider epoch ℓ\ellℓ. Let yℓ+1y_{\ell+1}yℓ+1​ be the solution constructed by the APPROX algorithm after running for TTT iterations starting with yℓy_\ellyℓ​ (so z0=yℓz_0 = y_\ellz0​=yℓ​).

Let y∗=arg⁡min⁡y∈E∥y−yℓ+1∥y^* = \arg\min_{y \in E} \|y - y_{\ell+1}\|y∗=argminy∈E​∥y−yℓ+1​∥ be the optimal solution closest to yℓ+1y_{\ell+1}yℓ+1​.

By Theorem 8 Analog with k=Tk = Tk=T:

Eξℓ[g(yℓ+1)−g(y∗)]≤8r2κ(T−1+2r)2((1−1r)(g(yℓ)−g(y∗))+2∥yℓ−y∗∥2)E_{\xi_\ell}[g(y_{\ell+1}) - g(y^*)] \leq \frac{8r^2 \kappa}{(T - 1 + 2r)^2} \left(\left(1 - \frac{1}{r}\right)(g(y_\ell) - g(y^*)) + 2\|y_\ell - y^*\|^2\right) Eξℓ​​[g(yℓ+1​)−g(y∗)]≤(T−1+2r)28r2κ​((1−r1​)(g(yℓ​)−g(y∗))+2∥yℓ​−y∗∥2)

From Step 3:

∥yℓ−y∗∥2≤4n2r(g(yℓ)−g(y∗))\|y_\ell - y^*\|^2 \leq 4n^2r (g(y_\ell) - g(y^*)) ∥yℓ​−y∗∥2≤4n2r(g(yℓ​)−g(y∗))

Therefore:

Eξℓ[g(yℓ+1)−g(y∗)]≤8r2κ(T−1+2r)2((1−1r)+2⋅4n2r)(g(yℓ)−g(y∗))E_{\xi_\ell}[g(y_{\ell+1}) - g(y^*)] \leq \frac{8r^2 \kappa}{(T - 1 + 2r)^2} \left(\left(1 - \frac{1}{r}\right) + 2 \cdot 4n^2r\right) (g(y_\ell) - g(y^*)) Eξℓ​​[g(yℓ+1​)−g(y∗)]≤(T−1+2r)28r2κ​((1−r1​)+2⋅4n2r)(g(yℓ​)−g(y∗))

=8r2κ(T−1+2r)2(1−1r+8n2r)(g(yℓ)−g(y∗))= \frac{8r^2 \kappa}{(T - 1 + 2r)^2} \left(1 - \frac{1}{r} + 8n^2r\right) (g(y_\ell) - g(y^*)) =(T−1+2r)28r2κ​(1−r1​+8n2r)(g(yℓ​)−g(y∗))

For large n,rn, rn,r, the dominant term is 8n2r8n^2r8n2r, so:

Eξℓ[g(yℓ+1)−g(y∗)]≤8r2κ⋅8n2r(T−1+2r)2(g(yℓ)−g(y∗))E_{\xi_\ell}[g(y_{\ell+1}) - g(y^*)] \leq \frac{8r^2 \kappa \cdot 8n^2r}{(T - 1 + 2r)^2} (g(y_\ell) - g(y^*)) Eξℓ​​[g(yℓ+1​)−g(y∗)]≤(T−1+2r)28r2κ⋅8n2r​(g(yℓ​)−g(y∗))

=64n2r3κ(T−1+2r)2(g(yℓ)−g(y∗))= \frac{64n^2r^3 \kappa}{(T - 1 + 2r)^2} (g(y_\ell) - g(y^*)) =(T−1+2r)264n2r3κ​(g(yℓ​)−g(y∗))

Epoch Length Calculation

To achieve a factor of 12\frac{1}{2}21​ improvement per epoch, we need:

64n2r3κ(T−1+2r)2≤12\frac{64n^2r^3 \kappa}{(T - 1 + 2r)^2} \leq \frac{1}{2} (T−1+2r)264n2r3κ​≤21​

This gives us:

(T−1+2r)2≥128n2r3κ(T - 1 + 2r)^2 \geq 128n^2r^3 \kappa (T−1+2r)2≥128n2r3κ

T−1+2r≥82nr3/2κ1/2T - 1 + 2r \geq 8\sqrt{2} nr^{3/2} \kappa^{1/2} T−1+2r≥82​nr3/2κ1/2

For large rrr, we can approximate:

T≥82nr3/2κ1/2≈11.31nr3/2κ1/2T \geq 8\sqrt{2} nr^{3/2} \kappa^{1/2} \approx 11.31 nr^{3/2} \kappa^{1/2} T≥82​nr3/2κ1/2≈11.31nr3/2κ1/2

To ensure the bound holds robustly, we choose:

T=16nr3/2κ1/2+1T = 16nr^{3/2} \kappa^{1/2} + 1 T=16nr3/2κ1/2+1

This gives us:

Eξℓ[g(yℓ+1)−g(y∗)]≤12(g(yℓ)−g(y∗))E_{\xi_\ell}[g(y_{\ell+1}) - g(y^*)] \leq \frac{1}{2} (g(y_\ell) - g(y^*)) Eξℓ​​[g(yℓ+1​)−g(y∗)]≤21​(g(yℓ​)−g(y∗))

Conclusion

From now on, here an iteration is defined as one pass through the entire set of edges ∣E∣=r=m|E| = r = m∣E∣=r=m for the convenience of comparison.

After ℓ\ellℓ epochs of the ACDM algorithm (equivalently, 16nrκℓ16n\sqrt{r\kappa}\ell16nrκ​ℓ iterations), we have:
E[g(yℓ+1)−g(y∗)]≤12ℓ+1(g(y0)−g(y∗))E[g(y_{\ell+1}) - g(y^*)] \leq \frac{1}{2^{\ell+1}}(g(y_0) - g(y^*))E[g(yℓ+1​)−g(y∗)]≤2ℓ+11​(g(y0​)−g(y∗))

where y∗=arg⁡min⁡y∈E∥y−yℓ+1∥y^* = \arg\min_{y \in E} \|y - y_{\ell+1}\|y∗=argminy∈E​∥y−yℓ+1​∥ is the optimal solution in EEE that is closest to yℓ+1y_{\ell+1}yℓ+1​.

Theorem 5.6

Suppose ∥g(y)−g(y∗)∥≤ϵ\|g(y)-g(y^*)\| \leq \epsilon∥g(y)−g(y∗)∥≤ϵ, then ∥y∥∞−∥y∗∥∞≤2κϵ\|y\|_{\infty}-\|y^*\|_{\infty} \leq 2 \sqrt {\kappa \epsilon}∥y∥∞​−∥y∗∥∞​≤2κϵ​

Now we can use the above result to give a guarantee for the ϵ\epsilonϵ-approximation c-DDS subproblem.

To solve the ϵ\epsilonϵ-approximation c-DDS subproblem, we need

∥y∥∞−∥y∗∥∞≤ϵ\|y\|_{\infty}-\|y^*\|_{\infty} \leq \epsilon ∥y∥∞​−∥y∗∥∞​≤ϵ

which requires:

∥g(y)−g(y∗)∥≤ϵ24κ\|g(y)-g(y^*)\| \leq \frac{\epsilon^2}{4\kappa} ∥g(y)−g(y∗)∥≤4κϵ2​

Thus, in expectation, we need to run the algorithm for ℓ\ellℓ epochs, where:

ℓ=log⁡2(g(y0)−g(y∗)ϵ2/(4κ))\ell = \log_2\left(\frac{g(y_0) - g(y^*)}{\epsilon^2/(4\kappa)}\right) ℓ=log2​(ϵ2/(4κ)g(y0​)−g(y∗)​)

We upper bound the $$|g(y_0) - g(y^*)|$$ by the maximum value of the objective function ggg.

Denote ψ(G)=max⁡{Δ+(G),Δ−(G)}\psi(G) = \max\{ \Delta^+(G), \Delta^-(G)\}ψ(G)=max{Δ+(G),Δ−(G)}, where Δ+(G)\Delta^+(G)Δ+(G) and Δ−(G)\Delta^-(G)Δ−(G) denote the maximum outdegree and indegree of directed graph GGG, respectively

We can show that g(y)=c∑u∈V(∑(u,v)∈Eαu,v)2+1c∑v∈V(∑(u,v)∈Eβv,u)2g(y) = \sqrt c \sum_{u\in V}\left(\sum_{(u,v) \in E}\alpha_{u,v}\right)^2 + \frac{1}{\sqrt{c}} \sum_{v\in V}\left(\sum_{(u,v) \in E}\beta_{v,u}\right)^2g(y)=c​∑u∈V​(∑(u,v)∈E​αu,v​)2+c​1​∑v∈V​(∑(u,v)∈E​βv,u​)2 is upper bounded by ψ(G)⋅∣E∣⋅κ\psi(G)\cdot |E| \cdot \kappaψ(G)⋅∣E∣⋅κ

Thus, we have:

ℓ=log⁡2(ψ(G)⋅∣E∣ϵ2)\ell = \log_2\left(\frac{\psi(G)\cdot |E|}{\epsilon^2}\right) ℓ=log2​(ϵ2ψ(G)⋅∣E∣​)

So we need to run the algorithm in iterations of

T⋅ℓ=16nmκlog⁡2(ψ(G)⋅∣E∣ϵ2)T \cdot \ell = 16n\sqrt{m\kappa} \log_2\left(\frac{\psi(G)\cdot |E|}{\epsilon^2}\right) T⋅ℓ=16nmκ​log2​(ϵ2ψ(G)⋅∣E∣​)

In terms of asymptotic complexity, this gives us:

O(nmκlog⁡(ψ(G)⋅mϵ2))\mathcal{O}\left(n\sqrt {m\kappa} \log\left(\frac{\psi(G)\cdot m}{\epsilon^2}\right)\right) O(nmκ​log(ϵ2ψ(G)⋅m​))

to solve a c-DDS subproblem.

The set of C is defined as

C={ab∣1≤a,b≤n,a,b∈Z+}C=\{\frac ab | 1\leq a,b \leq n, a,b \in \mathbb{Z}^+\} C={ba​∣1≤a,b≤n,a,b∈Z+}

For the DDS problem, define Φ=∑c∈Cmax⁡{c14,c−14}\Phi = \sum_{c\in C} \max\{c^{\frac 14},c^{-\frac 14}\}Φ=∑c∈C​max{c41​,c−41​}

Then the total complexity of solving all c-DDS subproblems is:

O(Φnmlog⁡(ψ(G)⋅mϵ2))\mathcal{O}\left(\Phi n\sqrt {m} \log\left(\frac{\psi(G)\cdot m}{\epsilon^2}\right)\right) O(Φnm​log(ϵ2ψ(G)⋅m​))
